{{EngvarB|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name = Republic of Singapore Air Force |native_name = {{nobold|{{native name|ms|Angkatan Udara Republik Singapura}}
{{native name|zh|新加坡空军部队|italics=off}}
{{native name|ta|சிங்கப்பூர் ஆகாயப்படை|italics=off}}}} |image=[[File:RSAF Crest.svg|200px]] |caption=The Republic of Singapore Air Force's crest |start_date={{start date and age|1975|04|01|df=yes}} |country={{Flagu|Singapore|size=23px}} |allegiance= |branch= |type=[[Air force]] |role=[[Air supremacy]], [[air defence|aerial defence]], [[aerial warfare]] |size=13,500 personnel, 276 aircraft |command_structure=[[Singapore Armed Forces]] |garrison= |garrison_label= |nickname="RSAF" |motto= |colours= |colors_label= |march= |mascot= |equipment= |equipment_label= |battles=[[Iraq War]], [[War in Afghanistan (2001-14)|War in Afghanistan]],As part of [[NATO]]-led [[International Security Assistance Force|ISAF]] [[Combined Task Force 151]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |notable_commanders= [[Bey Soo Khiang]]
[[Ng Chee Khern]]
[[Ng Chee Meng]]
[[Hoo Cher Mou]] |identification_symbol= [[File:Republic of Singapore Air Force service flag.svg|border|150px]] |identification_symbol_label= [[Air ensign|Ensign]] |identification_symbol_2= [[File:RSAF Roundel (1990–present).svg|76px]] [[File:RSAF Roundel (1990–present, low visibility).svg|76px]] |identification_symbol_2_label= Roundels |identification_symbol_3= [[File:State colour of the Republic of Singapore Air Force (1977-1993).png|150px|border]] |identification_symbol_3_label=Former flag (1977–1993) |identification_symbol_4= |identification_symbol_4_label= |aircraft_attack=[[McDonnell Douglas F-15E Strike Eagle#F-15SG|F-15SG]], [[Boeing AH-64 Apache#AH-64D|AH-64D]] |aircraft_bomber= |aircraft_electronic= |aircraft_fighter=[[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16C/D]], [[F-15SG]], [[F-5]] |aircraft_interceptor=[[Northrop F-5#F-5E and F-5F Tiger II|F-5S/T]] |aircraft_patrol=[[Northrop Grumman E-2 Hawkeye|E-2C]], [[Gulfstream G550#Government and military operators|G550 AEW&C]], [[Fokker 50|Fokker 50 ME2]] |aircraft_recon=[[Northrop F-5#Reconnaissance versions|RF-5S]] |aircraft_trainer=[[Alenia Aermacchi M-346 Master|M346]], [[Pilatus PC-21|PC-21]], [[ST Aerospace A-4SU Super Skyhawk|TA-4SU]], [[Eurocopter EC120 Colibri|EC120]] |aircraft_transport=[[Lockheed Martin KC-130|KC-130B]] & [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130H]], [[Fokker 50|Fokker 50 UTL]], [[Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker|KC-135R]], [[Boeing CH-47 Chinook|CH-47D/SD]], [[Eurocopter AS332 Super Puma|Super Puma]] |current_commander=Major General [[Mervyn Tan Wei Ming]] |current_commander_label=Chief of Air Force |ceremonial_chief= |ceremonial_chief_label= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |colonel_of_the_regiment_label= }} The '''Republic of Singapore Air Force''' ('''RSAF''') is the [[Air force|air arm]] of the [[Singapore Armed Forces]]. It was first established in 1968 as the Singapore Air Defence Command (SADC). In 1975, it was renamed the Republic of Singapore Air Force.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/mindef_websites/atozlistings/air_force/about/History.html|title=History of RSAF: OUR EARLY DAYS|date=2003 [updated 9 July 2010]|work=Wings on High: 35 Years of the Republic of Singapore Air Force|publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (Singapore)]] (MINDEF)|accessdate=3 June 2011}} ==History== [[File:Air Force Ensign of Singapore (1968-1973).svg|thumb|left|upright|Former Singaporean air force ensign, used from 1968 to 1973.]] [[File:Air force ensign of Singapore (1973-1990).svg|thumb|left|upright|Former Singaporean air force ensign, used from 1973 to 1990.]] In January 1968, the British announced the imminent withdrawal of all their troops east of Suez by the end of 1971. Prior to then, Singapore had depended completely on Britain's [[Royal Air Force]] (RAF) for its air defence, while the newly established [[Singapore Armed Forces]] (SAF) had concentrated its efforts mainly on building up the [[Singapore Army]]. {{multiple image |align= left |width= 85 |footer=
'''Comparison of older RSAF roundels'''
|image1= RSAF Roundel 1968-1973.svg |width1= |caption1= 1968–1973: 1st generation [[Royal Air Force roundels|RAF styled roundel]] (similar to [[Peruvian Air Force|Peruvian]] and [[Turkish Air Force]] roundels) |image2= RSAF Roundel 1973-1990.svg |width2= |caption2= 1973–1990: 2nd generation [[yin and yang|yin-yang]] styled roundel }} The predecessor to the RSAF, the SADC, was formed in September 1968. The SADC's immediate task was to set up the Flying Training School to train pilots. Qualified flying instructors were obtained through [[Airwork Services|Airwork Services Limited]], a UK-based company specialising in defence services. Basic training for pilots was carried out using two Cessna light aircraft hired from the Singapore Flying Club. The SADC also enlisted the help of the Royal Air Force which introduced the first flying training syllabus and provided two ex-RAF pilots as instructors, as well as facilities and services at [[Seletar Airport]]. Finally, the first batch of six pilot trainees were sent to the [[United Kingdom]] in August 1968 to undergo training in various technical disciplines. The training was based on the [[Hawker Hunter]], the SADC's first air defence fighter. The following month, another pioneer group of technicians, this time from the rotary wing, were sent to France to begin their technical training on the [[Aérospatiale Alouette III]] helicopter. In 1969, a number of local RAF technicians were released to join the fledging SADC. These [[RAF other ranks|local technicians (local other ranks)]] had experience working on fixed-wing RAF aircraft such as the Hawker Hunter, [[Gloster Javelin]], [[English Electric Canberra]], [[English Electric Lightning]] and [[Avro Shackleton]];Jefford 2001, pp. 48–49. as well as rotary-wing RAF aircraft such as the [[Bristol Belvedere]], [[Westland Wessex]] and [[Westland Whirlwind (helicopter)|Westland Whirlwind]]. Eight Cessna 172K aircraft – the SADC's first – arrived in May 1969 to be used for basic pilot training.{{cite web|title= Arrival of Cessna 172K – A Boost to our Fledgling Air Force|url= http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/about_us/history/birth_of_saf/v08n05_history.html|publisher=MINDEF|date=7 May 2004|accessdate=25 September 2008}} By December, the first batch of students completed the course. Of these, six were sent to the UK to receive further training. On their return to Singapore in 1970, they were ready to operate the then newly acquired Hawker Hunter fighter aircraft. The pace of training pilots and ground crew picked up gradually. On 1 August 1969, Minister for the Interior and Defence, [[Lim Kim San]], inaugurated the Flying Training School (FTS) at [[Tengah Air Base]] (then known as RAF Tengah). The inauguration of FTS brought SADC closer to its goal of fulfilling the heavy responsibility of defending Singapore's airspace. The subsequent arrival of the [[BAC Strikemaster]]s in 1969, used for advanced phase flying training, meant that pilot trainees were now able to earn their initial wings locally rather than overseas. The first batch of locally trained fighter pilots were trained at the FTS and graduated in November 1970. Amongst this batch was 2LT Goh Yong Siang, who later rose to the appointment of Chief of Air Force on 1 July 1995. Gradually, the SADC had its own pilots, flying instructors, air traffic controllers, and ground crew. When Britain brought forward its plan to withdraw its forces by September 1971, the SADC was suddenly entrusted with a huge responsibility and resources. Britain's former air bases – [[Tengah Air Base|Tengah]], [[Seletar Airport|Seletar]], [[Sembawang Air Base|Sembawang]] and [[Changi Air Base|Changi]] – were handed over to the SADC, as well as its air defence radar station and [[Bristol Bloodhound|Bloodhound II]] surface-to-air missiles. In 1973, the SADC procured [[Short SC.7 Skyvan|Shorts Skyvan]] search-and-locate aircraft and [[Douglas A-4 Skyhawk]] fighter-bombers. With a reliable mix of fighters, fighter-bombers, helicopters and transport aircraft, the SADC was ready to assume the functions of a full-fledged air force. On 1 April 1975, the SADC was renamed the Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF). One of its first commanders was LTC [[Ee Tean Chye]].{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19730123.2.28.aspx|title=VIP send-off for Gen Bulsak|date=23 January 1973|work=[[The Straits Times]]|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]|page=5|accessdate=3 June 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19720211.2.83.aspx|title=Mr. Lee hosts Istana dinner|date=11 February 1972|work=The Straits Times|publisher=Singapore Press Holdings|page=12|accessdate=3 June 2011}} '''Wars involving Singapore Air Force''': * 2004-2008 [[Multi-National Force – Iraq]]. Aircraft participated in the [[Iraq War]] and returned home after two or three months deployment in the [[Persian Gulf]] without any ground troops involved. Singapore's withdrawal was acknowledged on 23 December 2008. ==Organisation== The RSAF is led by the Chief of the Air Force (CAF). The current CAF is Major General [[Mervyn Tan Wei Ming]].{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/rsaf-welcomes-new-chief/2643106.html | title=RSAF welcomes new Chief of Air Force | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=28 March 2016 | accessdate=29 March 2016}} The CAF reports directly to the Chief of Defence Force and is assisted by the Chief of Staff (Air Staff), Brigadier General (BG) Lim Tuang Liang.{{cite web|url=http://app.sgdi.gov.sg/listing.asp?agency_subtype=dept&agency_id=0000000371|title=Singapore Government directory: Air Force HQ|publisher=[[Government of Singapore]]|accessdate=5 May 2015}} The Air Force Command Chief is Military Expert 6 (ME6) M. A. Pathi.{{cite web|url = http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/about_us/biographies/saf_leadership.html#tab-4|title = SAF Leadership|publisher = [[Ministry of Defence (Singapore)|MINDEF]]|accessdate = 21 Oct 2015}} The Air Staff comprises six functional departments: Air Manpower, Air Intelligence, Air Operations, Air Engineering and Logistics, Air Plans and Air Training. There are also two specialist departments: the Air Force Inspectorate (AFI) and the Office of the Chief Air Force Medical Officer (CAMO). === List of chiefs=== {|class="wikitable" style="width:70%" ! Years in Office ! Name |- |2016–present || [[Mervyn Tan]] Wei Ming |- | 2013–16 || [[Hoo Cher Mou]] |- | 2009–13 || [[Ng Chee Meng]] |- | 2006–9 || [[Ng Chee Khern]] |- | 2001–6 || [[Lim Kim Choon]] |- | 1998–2001 || Raymund Ng Teck Heng |- | Unknown–1998 || Goh Yong Siang |} On 5 January 2007, Defence minister [[Teo Chee Hean]] announced that the Air Force organisation chart will be re-structured into five major commands, namely the Air Defence and Operations Command (ADOC), the Air Combat Command (ACC), the Participation Command (PC), the Air Power Generation Command (APGC) and the Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) Command (UC). The first to be inaugurated was ADOC, along the restructuring announcement.http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/mindef_websites/atozlistings/air_force/about/command_centre.html ADOC is the principal agency in charge of planning and executing peacetime operations and air defence. ADOC is also responsible for the development and operational readiness of the command and control and ground-based air defence units of the RSAF. ADOC comprises Air Surveillance Control Group (ASCG), National Air Defence Group (ADG) and Air Operations Control Group (AOCG).http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/mindef_websites/atozlistings/air_force/assets/commands/adoc.html UAV Command was the second command to be inaugurated and become operational in May 2007.{{cite press release|title=Inauguration of the Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) Command|publisher=MINDEF|date=25 May 2007 [updated 24 July 2009]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2007/may/25may07_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} The main structures under UC are Operations & System Development Group (OSDG), headed by the Deputy Commander of UC and Squadrons and UAV Training School (UTS). The next command to be inaugurated was PC in January 2008. Participation Command comprises the Operations Development Group (ODG), the Helicopter Group (HeliG), the Tactical Air Support Group (TASG), and the Divisional Air Defence Group (DAG).{{cite press release|title=RSAF Inaugurates Participation Command|publisher=MINDEF|date=4 January 2008 [updated 28 May 2008]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2008/jan/04jan08_nr2.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} The last two commands, ACC and APGC, were inaugurated together in August 2008 in conjunction with the RSAF 40th Anniversary. The ACC will bring together fighter and transport squadrons under one command, with central planning, control and execution of the air battle in operations. The APGC will enhance the missions of the ACC by ensuring that all air bases remain operational at all times, as well as improving the servicing and turn-around of aircraft to ensure continuous and responsive operations. The ACC is responsible for the planning, control and execution of the air battle in operations. It brings together all fighter and transport squadrons that will carry out these tasks under a single command which will be responsible for training the pilots and aircrew to think and operate in a fully integrated way. The ACC consists of the Integrated System Development Group (ISDG), Operations Development Group (ODG), Fighter Group (FG) and Transport Group (TG). The APGC is set up to enable the RSAF to generate and sustain effective, timely and robust air power to meet the operational needs of the SAF. With the APGC, higher operational efficiency within each RSAF Air Base, and secondly, greater integration across the four bases are achieved. The APGC consists of the Operations Development Group (ODG) and four air bases: Changi Air Base, Paya Lebar Air Base, Sembawang Air Base and Tengah Air Base. The four support squadrons still remain organic to each Base but are under direct command of APGC. These four squadrons are: Airfield Maintenance Squadron (AMS), Ground Logistics Squadron (GLS), Field Defence Squadron (FDS) and Flying Support Squadron (FSS). The Air Force Training Command (AFTC) is an amalgamation of the former Air Force School, Flying Training School and UAV Training school which facilitates training of future pilots and ground crew of the RSAF. The training schools and squadrons under AFTC consist of the Flying Training Institute, Air Warfare Training Institute, and Air Engineering Training Institute. ==Overview== {{RSAF Infobox}} The backbone of the RSAF is formed by the Block 52/52+ [[F-16 Fighting Falcon]]s. These are armed with US-supplied [[AIM-120 AMRAAM|AIM-120C AMRAAM]] missiles and [[LANTIRN]] targeting pods, laser guided munitions and [[conformal fuel tank]]s for long-range strike. While Singapore initially bought as many as 70 F-16 planes, on 18 November 2004, it was announced that the RSAF would offer its remaining 7 F-16A/B's to the [[Royal Thai Air Force]]. It is believed that these early Block 15OCU aircraft were upgraded to "Falcon One" standard by [[ST Aerospace]] before the transfer and delivered in late 2005. In return, the RSAF was permitted to train at the [[Udon Thani International Airport|Udon Royal Thai Air Force Base]] in north-east Thailand for a specified number of days each year. This would mean that the RSAF will operate only the Block 52/52+ model, as many as 62 F-16CJ/DJ planes. Due to severe airspace constraints within Singapore, the RSAF operates its aircraft at several overseas locations to provide greater exposure to its pilots. With the F-16C/D Fighting Falcons, [[KC-135 Stratotanker|KC-135R Stratotankers]], [[AH-64 Apache|AH-64D Apaches]] and [[CH-47 Chinook#CH-47D|CH-47SD Chinook]] helicopters based in the United States, the [[Aermacchi S-211|Marchetti S-211s]], [[Pilatus PC-21|PC-21s]], and [[Eurocopter Super Puma|Super Puma]] helicopters in [[Australia]], and the [[A-4SU Super Skyhawk|TA-4SU Super Skyhawks]] in France, almost one third of the force's inventory is based outside Singapore. In 1994, the RSAF commenced a modernisation program for its fleet of approximately 49 operational (R)[[Northrop F-5#Singapore|F-5E and F-5F]] aircraft. The upgrade was performed by Singapore Technologies Aerospace (STAero) and the upgraded aircraft were designated (R)F-5S and F-5T respectively, operating from Paya Lebar Air Base. These upgraded F-5S/T, equipped with the Galileo Avionica's FIAR Grifo-F X-band Radar{{cite press release|title=Assets: Fighter aircraft|publisher=MINDEF|date=24 April 2010|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/mindef_websites/atozlistings/air_force/assets/aircraft/fighters.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}}{{cite magazine|last=Mike Yeo|date=March 2011|title=Tigers over Lion City|magazine=[[Air Forces Monthly]]|publisher=[[Key Publishing]]|location=[[London]]|issue= 275|pages=86–91|issn=0955-7091}}{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2000/04/11/64402/brazil-favours-grifo-f-radar-for-f-5br-upgrade.html|title=Brazil favours Grifo F radar for F-5BR upgrade: "The air force has test flown the Singapore air force's upgraded version of the F-5S/T, fitted with the Grifo F radar."|date=11 April 2000|work=[[Flightglobal.com]]|publisher=[[Reed Business Information]]|accessdate=3 June 2011|location=London}} are thought to be capable of firing the AIM-120 AMRAAM missile but to date, no actual live-firing has actually been reported. For [[in-flight refuelling]], four KC-135Rs and four [[Lockheed Martin KC-130|KC-130Bs]] are commissioned to support the fighter force of F-16C/Ds and (R)F-5S/Ts. [[Airborne Early Warning and Control]] (AEW&C) capability was introduced in 1987 when four [[E-2 Hawkeye|E-2C Hawkeyes]] were delivered to 111 Squadron. The duty of [[Maritime patrol|Maritime Patrol and Coastal surveillance]] is performed by the five Fokker 50 MPA (entered service in 1991) of 121 Squadron, which can be armed with long-range anti-shipping [[Harpoon (missile)|AGM-84 Harpoon]] missiles and ASW torpedoes. As part of its fleet renewal process, the RSAF officially withdrew its fleet of [[ST Aerospace A-4SU Super Skyhawk]] from front-line service on 31 March 2005 after 31 years of operations. The A-4SUs' achievements included flying directly from Singapore to the Philippines, incorporating the RSAF's first air-to-air refuelling mission in 1986, as well as the excellent aerobatic display of the 'red and white' Super Skyhawks flown by the [[RSAF Black Knights]] during Asian Aerospace 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/mindef_websites/atozlistings/air_force/assets/black_knights/history.html|title=RSAF Black Knights 2008: History|date=24 April 2010|publisher=MINDEF|accessdate=3 June 2011}} A month before its retirement, the Skyhawk squadron won top honours in a strike exercise against its more modern F-16 and F-5 counterparts. Singapore ordered a total of twenty [[AH-64 Apache|AH-64D Apache Longbow]] attack helicopters in two batches. After a long period of negotiations over the delivery of the sophisticated Longbow [[Fire-control radar]], the first batch of eight aircraft, fitted with the Fire Control Radar, was delivered on 17 May 2002.{{cite press release|title=Singapore Receives First AH-64D Apache Longbow Attack Helicopter|publisher=MINDEF|date=18 May 2002 [updated 26 June 2006]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2002/may/18may02_nr2.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} The second batch of 12 Apaches were ordered in 2001 even before the first delivery took place.{{cite press release|title=Singapore to Purchase 12 Additional Boeing AH-64D Apache Longbows|publisher=[[Boeing]]|date=23 August 2001|url=http://www.boeing.com/news/releases/2001/q3/nr_010823o.htm|accessdate=3 June 2011}} All of the initial eight Apaches are based in the United States. Three of the Apache Longbows returned in January 2006 at the request of the Minister of Defence. Apart from the six CH-47SDs delivered from 1996, a new batch of six aircraft was ordered in 1997, with an option of four extra airframes. At least 12 CH-47SD have been delivered and are in service at Sembawang Air Base. It is believed that these had been upgraded to the SD standard prior to delivery. Eight CH-47SDs were also deployed to support the relief efforts in the aftermath of the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|Indonesian Tsunami]]. It was the first and one of the few countries to reach the affected areas. The RSAF deployed dozens of C-130Hs, CH-47SDs and AS 332Ms there along with three of the RSN's latest Landing Ship Tanks (RSS Endurance, RSS Persistence and RSS Endeavour of the [[Endurance class landing platform dock ship|''Endurance'' class LST]]) as well as [[Singapore Armed Forces]] vehicles, engineers, and medical teams. In September 2005, the RSAF sent three CH-47SD Chinook helicopters, later augmented by a fourth CH-47SD Chinook, to provide assistance in the rescue and evacuation of stranded civilians after [[Hurricane Katrina]] struck New Orleans and nearby areas in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://usinfo.state.gov/gi/Archive/2005/Sep/08-339829.html|title=Asia-Pacific Opens Hearts, Wallets to U.S. Victims of Katrina|last=Jane A. Morse|date=8 September 2005|work=The Washington File|publisher=[[United States Department of State]]|accessdate=3 June 2011|archiveurl=http://usinfo.org/wf-archive/2005/050908/epf402.htm|archivedate=8 September 2010}} The [[Singaporean response to Hurricane Katrina|humanitarian effort by Singapore]] involved more aircraft than any other foreign countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.helis.com/featured/katrina.php|title=Hurricane Katrina: International helicopters Response|publisher=Helicopter History Site|accessdate=3 June 2011}} Since 2003, the RSAF has also made deployments of KC-135 tankers and C-130 aircraft to the [[Persian Gulf]] in support of the multinational efforts for the [[reconstruction of Iraq]]. RSAF personnel have carried out airlift, transportation and supply, and air-to-air refuelling missions in support of the multinational forces, assisting the [[Multinational force in Iraq|Coalition]] in carrying supplies and personnel, transporting humanitarian material and conducting medical evacuation operations.{{cite press release|title=SAF KC-135 Deployment to Aid in the Reconstruction of Iraq|publisher=MINDEF|date=9 June 2004 [updated 15 June 2005]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2004/jun/09jun04_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}}{{cite press release|title=SAF Deploys LST and C-130 to Assist in Reconstruction of Iraq|publisher=MINDEF|date=27 October 2003 [updated 4 July 2008]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2003/oct/27oct03_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} In September 2013, Defence Minister [[Ng Eng Hen]] stated in a parliamentary reply that Singapore would soon acquire the [[Aster (missile family)#Land systems|Aster 30]] land-based missile system.http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/press_room/official_releases/ps/2013/16sep13_ps.html#.Ujy6M5ygtyE ==Air bases== [[File:RSAF F-5 preparing to take off.jpg|thumb|An F-5S of 144 Sqn preparing for take-off.]] [[File:RSAF F-16 in alert fighter taxi-ing.jpg|thumb|An F-16C of 140 Sqn scrambling.]] [[File:M113A2 Ultra Mechanised Igla.jpg|thumb|Demonstration of a M-113A2 Ultra Mechanised Igla IFU on deployment, visible in the background is an [[MIM-23 Hawk|I-HAWK SAM launcher]].]] [[File:Republic of Singapore Air Force IAI Searcher II Unmanned Aerial Vehicle at Henry Post Army Airfield, Fort Sill, Lawton, Oklahoma - 20091114.jpg|thumb|Exercise Forging Sabre 2009, an RSAF's IAI Searcher II UAV parked inside the hangar of [[Henry Post Army Airfield]], United States.]] {{Outdated section|date=October 2015}} * '''[[Changi Air Base (West)]]''' ** [[112 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|112 Sqn]] 4 KC-135R (Aerial refuelling) ** [[121 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|121 Sqn]] 4 Fokker 50 (Transport), 5 Fokker 50 ME2 (Maritime patrol) * '''[[Changi Air Base (East)]]''' ** [[145 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|145 Sqn]] 20 F-16D Blk 52+ (Strike) * '''[[Paya Lebar Air Base]]''' ** [[122 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|122 Sqn]] 6 C-130H (Transport), 5 KC-130B (Transport/Aerial refuelling) ** [[141 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|141 Sqn]] - stood down in 2000s ** [[142 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|142 Sqn]] 18 T/A-4SU Super Skyhawks (Fighter-bomber) – stood down in 2004 and were replaced by 15 F-15SG http://www.maphotosg.com/rsaf-new-old-142sqn-flying-f-15sg/ ** [[144 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|144 Sqn]] 15 F-5S (Interceptor), 7 F-5T (Training/Interceptor) ** [[149 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|149 Sqn]] 15 F-5S (Interceptor), 1 F-5T (Training/Interceptor), 18 F-15SG * '''[[Sembawang Air Base]]''' ** [[120 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|120 Sqn]] 20 AH-64D Longbow Apache (Attack) ** [[123 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|123 Sqn]] 6 S-70B Seahawks (ASW) ** [[124 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|124 Sqn]] 4 EC120 Colibri (Training) ** [[125 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|125 Sqn]] 22 AS332M Super Puma (Transport/SAR) ** [[126 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|126 Sqn]] 12 AS532UL Cougar (Transport/SAR) ** [[127 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|127 Sqn]] 6 CH-47D, 12 CH-47SD (Heavylift) * '''[[Tengah Air Base]]''' ** [[111 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|111 Sqn]] 4 G550 (AEW & C) ** 116 Sqn Hermes 450 (Reconnaissance) ** [[140 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|140 Sqn]] 9 F-16C (Interceptor), 6 F-16D Blk 52 (Strike) ** [[143 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|143 Sqn]] 5 F-16C (Interceptor), 8 F-16D Blk 52 (Strike) ** [[RSAF Black Knights]] – RSAF's aerobatic team. * '''[[Chong Pang Camp]] SADA (Singapore Air Defence Artillery)''' ** 3rd DA RBS-70 SAM, IGLA SAM, Giraffe Radar ** 6th DA RBS-70 SAM, IGLA SAM, Giraffe Radar ** 9th DA RBS-70 SAM, IGLA SAM, Giraffe Radar ** 18th DA RBS-70 SAM, Mistral SAM ** 160 Sqn Oerlikon 35 mm AA Guns (Airfield defence) * '''[[Lim Chu Kang Camp II]] SADA (Singapore Air Defense Artillery)''' ** 163 Sqn Raytheon I-HAWK SAM (Medium altitude air defence)(*being replaced by Aster 30 SMTP) ** [[165 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|165 Sqn]] Rapier SAM, RBS-70 SAM, SPYDER SAM * '''[[Danau Camp]]''' ** 201 Sqn FPS 117 Radar (Fighter control, SAM control, Surveillance, ASP) * '''Other assets of SADA (Singapore Air Defense Artillery)''' ** 203 Sqn LORADS Radar (RASP, SAR, "listening watch" for distress signals) * '''[[Murai Camp]]''' ** 119 Sqn IAI Heron (Reconnaissance) ** 128 Sqn 400 IAI Searcher (Reconnaissance) ==Personnel== {{Main|Singapore Armed Forces ranks}} Military ranks in the Singapore Armed Forces are identical across the three services except for the flag ranks of the [[Republic of Singapore Navy|RSN]]. They are based on the Army model. The official table of ranks stops at three stars for all three services.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/mindef_websites/atozlistings/air_force/about/Ranks.html|title=About us: Ranks|year=2011|publisher=MINDEF|accessdate=3 June 2011}} [[NATO]] rank codes are not officially used, but are listed here for easy comparison with other armed forces. Like the [[Republic of Singapore Navy|Navy]], the majority of Air Force personnel are regulars. This is due to the specialised and technical nature of many jobs. The employment of [[Conscription in Singapore|National Servicemen]] in various roles are limited mostly to the infantry-like Field Defence Squadrons which do not require such specialised training. ==Overseas detachments (Training)== {{multiple image |align= right |width= 150 |footer =
'''Super Skyhawks in France'''
|image1= 933 at TA-4SU Skyhawk of the Singapore Air Force.jpg |width1= |caption1= 2004, TA-4SU (933) on the flightline of Cazaux Air Base |image2= RSAF A-4SU Super Skyhawks at Istres Air Base.jpg |width2= |caption2= 6 June 2010, a pair of A-4SU Super Skyhawks (serials 938 & 909) on static display during an [[air show]] at the [[Istres-Le Tubé Air Base|Istres Air Base]] }} [[File:RSAF Pearce.JPG|thumb|The RSAF Flying Training School at [[RAAF Base Pearce]]]] * [[Cazaux Air Base|BA 120 Cazaux Airbase (France)]]{{cite web|url=http://www.airshows.co.uk/reports/overseas/2005/cazaux-airshow-spotters-day/|title=Cazaux Airshow / Spotters Day 2005 Review: "Situated South West of Bordeaux is station BA120 Cazaux"|date=12 June 2005|publisher=Airshows.co.uk|accessdate=3 June 2011}} ** 150 Sqn, 12 x [[Alenia Aermacchi M-346 Master|Alenia Aermacchi M-346]] {{cite web|url=https://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/press_room/official_releases/nr/2014/sep/03sep14_nr2.html|title=The RSAF Inaugurates the M-346 into 150 Squadron|last=|first=|date=February 2011|website=|publisher=Asian Military Review|author=Adam Baddeley|accessdate=11 July 2011}} * '''Redmond Taylor AHP – Grand Prairie AASF (Grand Prairie, Texas)''' ** 149th AVN, 6 × CH-47SD (Peace Prairie CH-47 Training){{cite press release|title=RSAF Celebrates 10 Years of Chinook Training in the US|publisher=MINDEF|date=23 April 2005 [updated 20 June 2005]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2005/apr/23apr05_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} * '''[[Luke Air Force Base]] (United States)''' ** [[425th Fighter Squadron|425 FTS]], 8 × F-16C, 6 × F-16D ([[F-16 Fighting Falcon operators#Summaries of F-16 deliveries|Peace Carvin II F-16 Training]]){{cite web|url=http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=12005|title=Fact Sheets: 425 Fighter Squadron (AETC)|last=Patsy Robertson|date=29 May 2009|work=[[Air Force Historical Research Agency]] (AFHRA)|publisher=[[United States Air Force]] (USAF)|accessdate=3 June 2011}} * '''[[Mountain Home Air Force Base]] (United States)''' ** [[428th Fighter Squadron|428 FTS]], 10 × F-15SG, (Peace Carvin V F-15 Training){{cite web|url=http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=10743|title=Fact Sheets: 428 Fighter Squadron (ACC)|last=Patsy Robertson|date=29 May 2009|work=AFHRA|publisher=USAF|accessdate=3 June 2011}} * '''[[Oakey Army Aviation Centre]] (Australia)''' ** [[126 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|126 Sqn]], 120 × AS532UL Cougar (Training/Support for army exercises){{cite press release|title=Opening Ceremony of the RSAF Helicopter Detachment in Oakey, Australia|publisher=MINDEF|date=20 August 1999 [updated 14 June 2005]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/1999/aug/20aug99_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} * '''[[RAAF Base Pearce]] (Australia)''' ** 130 Sqn, 19 × PC-21 (Basic Training){{cite press release|title=Australia-Singapore Defence Relationship|publisher=MINDEF|date=17 October 1996 [updated 26 June 2005]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/press_room/official_releases/nr/1996/oct/17oct96_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} * '''Silverbell Army Heliport (United States)''' ** E/1-285th AVN, 8 × AH-64D (Peace Vanguard AH-64D Training){{cite press release|title=Minister for Defence Visits the US|publisher=MINDEF|date=8 May 2004 [updated 15 June 2005]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2004/may/08may04_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} ==Aircraft== [[File:RSAF at Mountain Home AFB.JPG|thumb|F-15SG of the [[428th Fighter Squadron]] at [[Mountain Home Air Force Base]]]] The [[McDonnell Douglas F-15E Strike Eagle#F-15SG|F-15SG Strike Eagle]] is a variant of the F-15E Strike Eagle and is similar in configuration to the F-15K sold to [[South Korea]], but differs in the addition of the [[APG-63 and APG-70#AN/APG-63(V)3|APG-63(V)3]] active electronically scanned array (AESA) radar developed by [[Raytheon]]. The F-15SG will be powered by two [[General Electric]] [[General Electric F110|F110-GE-129]] {{convert|29400|lbf|kN|abbr=on}} thrust engines. In February 2003, Singapore joined the [[F-35 Lightning II#Security Cooperative Participants (SCP)|JSF program's]] System Design and Development (SDD) Phase, as a Security Co-operation Participant (SCP).{{cite press release|title=Singapore Signs Letter of Intent for Joint Strike Fighter Programme|publisher=MINDEF|date=22 February 2003 [updated 17 March 2006]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2003/feb/22feb03_nr2.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}}{{cite press release|title=Singapore Joins Joint Strike Fighter Programme|publisher=MINDEF|date=16 March 2004 [updated 4 June 2010]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2004/mar/16mar04_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} The first deliveries of the F-35 are not expected before 2015, but replacement for some of the [[ST Aerospace A-4SU Super Skyhawk]]s was needed by 2007. As a start, 20 F-16D Block 52+ have been delivered from 2003 under project Peace Carvin IV.The initial order is for 12 aircraft with 8 options. Eventually, as many as 40 to 60 aircraft may be procured in several batches. Pending news on [[Lockheed Martin]]'s [[F-35 Lightning II]]'s progress, it is speculated that more F-15SGs may be bought, with the upper limit, as disclosed by the RSAF, being 80 F-15SG aircraft in total. On 22 October 2007, Singapore's Ministry of Defence (MINDEF) exercised the option to purchase eight more F-15SG fighters as part of the original contract signed in 2005. Along with this buy, an additional order for four F-15SGs was made, bringing the total number of F-15SGs purchased to 24. {{citation needed|date=August 2016}} The RSAF embarked on its Next Generation Fighter (NGF) programme to replace the ageing A-4SU Super Skyhawks. The original list of competitors was shortlisted to the final two – [[Dassault Rafale]] and the [[F-15E Strike Eagle#F-15SG|F-15SG Strike Eagle]]. The DSTA (Defense Science & Technology Agency) conducted detailed technical assessment, simulations and other tests to assess the final selection. On 6 September 2005, it was announced that the Boeing F-15SG Strike Eagle had won the contract over the Rafale.{{cite press release|title=Singapore Seals Deal to Acquire Twelve F-15SG|publisher=MINDEF|date=12 December 2005 [updated 18 April 2006]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2005/dec/12dec05_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} [[File:Singapore Peace Triton S-70B.jpg|thumb|left|A Singapore Peace Triton S-70B being guided by a member of the RSN on the flight line of [[Naval Air Station North Island]]]] In January 2005, it was announced that 6 [[Sikorsky S-70]]B (derivative of [[SH-60 Seahawk]]) naval helicopters will be purchased, complete with anti-surface and anti-submarine weapons and sensors.{{cite press release|title=Republic of Singapore Navy Acquires Six New Naval Helicopters|publisher=MINDEF|date=21 January 2005 [updated 8 June 2005]|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2005/jan/21jan05_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}} These will be operated by RSAF pilots, with System Specialists of the [[Republic of Singapore Navy]] operating the sensors and weaponry. They will operate from the Navy's new [[Formidable class frigate|''Formidable'' class frigates]], and when operating from land will be based at Sembawang Air Base. All 20 AH-64D Longbow attack helicopters have been delivered, achieving pilot IOC. 12 of these Longbow Apaches were deployed back to Singapore and took part in combined arms exercises with the Army. In April 2007, it was announced that the 4 E-2C Hawkeyes were to be replaced with 4 Gulfstream G550s which would become the primary airborne early warning aircraft for the RSAF.{{cite press release|title=Factsheet: G550 – Airborne Early Warning|publisher=MINDEF|date=23 April 2007|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2007/apr/23apr07_nr/23apr07_fs3.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.defense-update.com/newscast/0507/news_080507.htm#g550|title=Singapore to Replace Hawkeye With G550 AEW|date=8 May 2007|publisher=Defense-Update.Com|accessdate=3 June 2011}} Not included in the deal is an additional G550 as an AEW trainer, which will be acquired and maintained by ST Aerospace on behalf of RSAF.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/channels/finance/articles/2008/09/16/316068/singapore-to-get-additional-g550-as-aew-trainer.html|title=Singapore to get additional G550 as AEW trainer|author=Craig Hoyle|date=16 September 2008|publisher=FlightGlobal.com|accessdate=28 June 2011}} [[File:ROSAF Lockheed Hercules DRW Butler.jpg|thumb|An RSAF C-130 Hercules over [[Darwin International Airport]]]] In July 2010, the [[Alenia Aermacchi M-346 Master]] was selected by the RSAF to replace the A-4SU Super Skyhawks in the Advanced Jet Training (AJT) role, currently based at '''BA 120 Cazaux Air Base''' in France.{{cite web|url=http://www.janes.com/news/defence/jdi/jdi100712_1_n.shtml|title=Alenia Aermacchi's M-346 wins Singapore jet trainer race|date=12 July 2010|publisher=[[Jane's Information Group]]|accessdate=16 July 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/07/08/344212/singapore-to-announce-m-346-trainer-selection.html|title=Singapore to announce M-346 trainer selection|last=Govindasamy|first=Siva|date=8 July 2010|work=Flightglobal.com|publisher=Reed Business Information|accessdate=16 July 2010|location=London}} And in a press release by the [[Ministry of Defence (Singapore)|Singaporean Ministry of Defence]] on 28 September 2008, [[ST Aerospace]] had been awarded the contract to acquire twelve M-346 and a ground based training system on behalf of RSAF. As stipulated in the contract, ST Aerospace will act as the main contractor to maintain the aircraft after delivery by Alenia Aermacchi while [[Boeing Defense, Space & Security|Boeing]] would supply the training system. Delivery date is scheduled from 2012 onwards.{{cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1083817/1/.html|title=MINDEF awards contract to ST Aerospace to acquire 12 M-346 aircraft|last=S.|first=Ramesh|date=28 September 2010|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]|accessdate=28 September 2010|location=Singapore}}{{cite press release|title=New Generation Advanced Fighter Trainer for the RSAF|publisher=MINDEF|date=28 September 2010|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/news_and_events/nr/2010/sep/28sep10_nr.html|accessdate=3 June 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_584003.html|title=New fighter trainer for RSAF|date=28 September 2010|work=The Straits Times|publisher=Singapore Press Holdings|accessdate=3 June 2011}} The backbone of the transport fleet are the four KC-130B, one KC-130H and five C-130H Hercules transport aircraft, which are expected to remain in service through 2030, will be undergoing an extensive modernisation process to bring all ten existing airframe to the same common standard. The first airframe, a KC-130B, was returned to frontline service on 21 September 2010. ST Aerospace, the main contractor behind the project, is expected to upgrade the other nine airframes for the RSAF within the next seven years. Included in the package is the replacement of cockpit [[flight management system]] with a modern [[glass cockpit]] avionics suite, central engine displays to replace analogue gauges, improved voice communications, digital autopilot, flight director as well as a digital weather radar, which will make the aircraft [[Global Air Traffic Management]]-compliant. Also, the C-130Bs will receive an [[auxiliary power unit]] and [[Environmental Control System|environmental control system]] in common with the C-130Hs. Once the upgrade is completed, this will effectively give the RSAF five refueller KC-130Hs and five Cargo C-130Hs.{{cite web|url=http://www.key.aero/view_news.asp?ID=2529&thisSection=military|title=Singapore gets first upgraded C-130|author=Gary Parsons|date=21 September 2010|publisher=Key Publishing|accessdate=28 June 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/11/12/349670/singapores-c-130-upgrade-makes-progress.html|title=Singapore's C-130 upgrade makes progress|author=Greg Waldron|date=12 November 2010|publisher=FlightGlobal.com|accessdate=28 June 2011}} In December 2010, the RSAF issued a letter of request to inspect stored ex-US Navy [[P-3C Orion]] aircraft that have been retired from active duty. Lockheed Martin believes the RSAF has a requirement of 4 to 5 of these aircraft, which would be modernised extensively before reintroduction into active service.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/12/15/350934/singapore-interested-in-ex-us-navy-p-3s.html|title=Singapore interested in ex-US Navy P-3s|last=Craig Hoyle|date=15 December 2010|publisher=Flightglobal.com|accessdate=3 June 2011}} ==Equipment== {{Main|Equipment of the Republic of Singapore Air Force}} ===Aircraft=== ====Current==== [[File:RSAF Boeing F-15SG Strike Eagle DRW Butler.jpg|thumb|RSAF F-15SG at [[Darwin International Airport]], 2011.]] [[File:RSAF Boeing KC-135R Stratotanker Pryde.jpg|thumb|RSAF KC-135R at [[Avalon Airport]], 2001.]] [[File:RSAF Aerospatiale AS-332M1 Super Puma Vabre.jpg|thumb|RSAF AS532UL Cougar at Avalon Airport, 2009.]] {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="6"| [[Military transport aircraft|Transport]] |- |[[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130 Hercules]] |[[United States]] |transport |[[Lockheed C-130 Hercules#Variants|C-130H]] |6 | |- |[[Fokker 50]] | [[Netherlands]] | transport | |4 | |- ! colspan="6"| [[Helicopters]] |- |[[Boeing AH-64 Apache|AH-64]] | [[United States]] |attack |[[Boeing AH-64 Apache#AH-64D|AH-64D]] |20 | |- |[[Boeing CH-47 Chinook|Boeing CH-47]] |[[United States]] |transport / utility |[[Boeing CH-47 Chinook#Other export models|CH-47SD]] |24 | |- |[[Sikorsky SH-60 Seahawk|Sikorsky SH-60]] | [[United States]] |[[Anti-surface warfare|ASW]] / [[Search and rescue|SAR]] |[[Sikorsky SH-60 Seahawk#Export versions|S-70B]] |6 |12 on order |- |[[Eurocopter AS332 Super Puma|Eurocopter AS332]] |[[France]] |utility / transport | |46 | |- ! colspan="6"| [[Trainer (aircraft)|Trainer Aircraft]] |- | [[Northrop F-5]] | [[United States]] | conversion trainer | [[Northrop F-5#Variants|F-5T]] | 9 | |- |[[Alenia Aermacchi M-346 Master|Alenia M-346]] | [[Italy]] |primary trainer | |12 | |- | [[Pilatus PC-21]] | [[Switzerland]] | trainer | | 19 | |- |[[Eurocopter EC120 Colibri|Eurocopter EC120]] |[[France]] |trainer | |4 | |} ====Historic==== =====Fixed-wing aircraft===== [[File:RSAF Hawker Hunter (front).jpg|thumb|A retired [[140 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|140 Sqn]] Hawker Hunter FGA.74S – serial number 527 (ex-RAF XF458), parked outside the RSAF Museum. Note also the number of hardpoints and the ADEN gun ports which had been [[Aircraft fairing|faired]] over to protect this museum piece against the weather.]] * (UK) [[Hawker Hunter]] — 12× FGA.74, 26× FR.74A/B, and 8× T.75/A (excluding one T.75A which was lost in accident before delivery) were delivered to RSAF in 1970 and 1973. Upgraded in the late 1970s by Lockheed Aircraft Services Singapore (LASS), the type was redesignated as FGA.74S, FR.74S and T.75S. Retired and phased out of service in 1992, only 4 were preserved as museum exhibits and gate guards while the remaining 21 airworthy airframes was sold to an Australian [[Warbird]] broker, Pacific Hunter Aviation Pty, in 1995.{{cite magazine|last=Peter|first=Atkins|date=November 1994|title=Singapore or Bust|magazine=Air Forces Monthly|publisher=Key Publishing|location=London|issue= 67|issn=0955-7091}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pacific-hunter-aviation.com.au/sales1.html|title=Hunter for sale|publisher=Pacific Hunter Aviation|accessdate=15 April 2011}} * (US) [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon]] — 4× F-16As and 4× F-16Bs delivered in 1988 under the [[F-16 Fighting Falcon operators#Summaries of F-16 deliveries|Peace Carvin I program]], one F-16A was lost following a mid-air collision with another F-16A over South China Sea in 1991. All surviving airframes were retired in 2002 and was subsequently upgraded locally to "Falcon One" standard by ST Aerospace before being transferred to [[Royal Thai Air Force]] in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.f-16.net/f-16_users_article17.html|title=F-16: Republic of Singapore Air Force|publisher=www.f-16.net/|accessdate= 30 December 2008}} * (UK) [[Short SC.7 Skyvan]] — 6× Skyvan 3Ms delivered in 1973 and retired in 1993. * (UK) [[BAC Jet Provost]] — 5× T.52s (ex-South Yemen Air Force airframe) operated from the 1975 until 1980.[http://www.caa.co.uk/application.aspx?catid=60&pagetype=65&appid=1&mode=detailnosummary&fullregmark=PROV UK Civil Aviation Authority Aircraft Register – Entry for former Singapore AF Jet Provost T52 registered G-PROV]Andrade 1982, page 192 * (UK) [[BAC Strikemaster]] — total 25 received (16× Mk.84s delivered in 1969 from UK plus 4× Mk.81s from South Yemen in 1975 and another 5× Mk.82s from Oman in 1977), all were retired in 1984 with one airframe preserved at the RSAF Museum while the remaining 13 airworthy airframes were sold to a Warbird broker.{{cite web|url=http://www.bacstrikemaster.co.uk/history/|title=HISTORY OF THE STRIKEMASTER|year=2010|publisher=BACStrikemaster.co.uk|accessdate=3 June 2011}} * (US) [[Cessna 172]] — 8× F172Ks delivered in 1969, retired in 1972. * (US) [[Lockheed T-33 Shooting Star]] — 20× T-33As (ex-[[French Air Force]] airframes), operated from 1980 until retired in 1985. * (Italy) [[Aermacchi SF.260|SIAI-Marchetti SF.260]] — 14× SF.260Ms delivered in 1971 plus 12× SF.260Ws delivered in 1979 and 1981. All remaining 19 airworthy airframes retired in 2002 and transferred to the [[Indonesian Air Force]].{{cite web|url=http://www.siai-marchetti.nl/sf260mil.html|title=SF.260 in military service|last=Hendrik van der Veen|date=31 December 2007|publisher=www.siai-marchetti.nl|accessdate=3 June 2011}} * (Italy) [[Aermacchi S-211|SIAI-Marchetti S.211]] — Since 1984, 32× S.211s were acquired for RSAF's Basic Jet Training (BJT) program (this figure includes 24 airframes which were assembled locally by [[ST Aerospace|Singapore Aircraft Industries]] plus two former Haitian aircraft acquired as attrition replacements in 1994). Phased out from June 2008, of the remaining 25 airworthy S.211s, 21 were sold off to International Air Parts (IAP) Group Australia Pty Ltd in 2009 while 4 were shipped back to Singapore, being preserved as museum exhibits.{{cite web|url=http://www.siai-marchetti.nl/s211pro.html|title=SIAI-MARCHETTI S.211 production list|last=Hendrik van der Veen|date=16 October 2010|publisher=siai-marchetti.nl|accessdate=3 June 2011}} =====Rotary-wing aircraft===== [[File:Aérospatiale Alouette III at the Republic of Singapore Air Force Museum.jpg|thumb|A retired [[120 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force|120 Sqn]] ''Alouette III'' (SA316B) on static display at the RSAF Museum]] * (France) [[Aérospatiale Alouette III]] — 8× SA316Bs delivered in 1969, retired and transferred to [[Royal Malaysian Air Force]] in 1978.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/safti/pointer/back/suppleme/1999/Sep/1.htm|title="Pointer", SAF Journal: 30 Years of Helicopter Operations|publisher=MINDEF}} * (France) [[Eurocopter AS350|Eurocopter AS350 Ecureuil]] — 7× AS350Bs for basic helicopter training, all delivered between 1981/82 and retired in 1992. * (France) [[Eurocopter Fennec|Eurocopter AS550 Fennec]] — 6× AS550A2 + 14× AS550C2, all delivered in 1991 and was retired in December 2006. Subsequently, the six AS550A2 were sold off to [[Chadian Air Force]] in 2010. * (US) [[Bell UH-1 Iroquois#Variant overview|Bell UH-1B]] — 20× UH-1Bs (refurbished ex-[[US Army]] airframes not including 10 spares) for advance helicopter training, operated from 1980 until 1988. * (US) [[Bell UH-1 Iroquois#Variant overview|Bell UH-1H]] — total 25 acquired, all are now retired except for 7 airframes which were refurbished and modernised before resale to the [[Philippine Air Force]] in a 2003 {{US$|12 million}} deal. * (US) [[Bell UH-1N Twin Huey]] — 3× UH-1Ns (military version of the [[Bell 212]] Twin Huey) delivered in 1977, all retired in 1985 and sold to [[Sri Lanka Air Force]]. ===Weaponry=== ====Current==== [[File:RSAF F-16D Block 52+ Fighting Falcon with Conformal Fuel Tanks.jpg|thumb|A fully bombed-up F-16D+ of 145 Sqn on static display during RSAF Open House 2008]] [[File:RSAF F-16D Block 52+ Fighting Falcon with Conformal Fuel Tanks 02.jpg|thumb|Rear view of the same aircraft]] 2010|publisher=MINDEF|accessdate=29 June 2011}} |{{SWE}} |Mobile Air Defense Radar |4/2 | |} ====Former==== =====Air-defence===== * (UK) [[Bristol Bloodhound]] Mk.II SAM – ex-RAF stock (total 88 missiles), all retired in 1994. ==Others== ===RSAF Black Knights=== {{Main|RSAF Black Knights}} {{Commons category|RSAF Black Knights}} First formed in 1973 at Tengah Air Base, the '''Black Knights''' is RSAF's official aerobatic team and has been performing on an ad-hoc basis since its inception, with volunteer pilots drawn from various front line squadrons within the RSAF. The aerobatics team has performed on events including the recent Singapore Airshow 2014. ===RSAF Museum=== {{Commons category|Republic of Singapore Air Force Museum}} [[File:Republic of Singapore Air Force museum.JPG|thumb|The RSAF Museum]] The RSAF maintains the Air Force Museum, which was first located at Changi Air Base before it was relocated to a purpose-built building currently situated along Airport Road adjacent to Paya Lebar Air Base. The museum is open to the public and showcases the air force's history and capabilities. ===ITE College Central=== The Republic of Singapore Air Force has donated several aircraft, and aircraft parts to the Institute of Technical Education (ITE) College Central. Mainly the SIAI-Marchetti S211. ==In popular culture== '''Fictional [[Television programs]]''' * ''[[Airforce (TV series)|Airforce]]'' (空军), 10 April 1988: This Chinese language drama series was filmed and produced by [[Singapore Broadcasting Corporation]] (now defunct, a forerunner of [[MediaCorp TV]], Singapore). {{YouTube|4W8VZjYkSRw|Theme song of this drama series.}} ==See also== * [[List of Republic of Singapore Air Force squadrons]] * [[MAAF (Singapore Wing)]] * [[Singapore Armed Forces ranks]] ==References== ;Citations {{Reflist|2}} ;Bibliography {{Refbegin}} * {{Cite book|last=Andrade|first=John|title=Militair 1982|year=1982|publisher=Aviation Press Limited|location= London|isbn=0-907898-01-7}} * {{Cite book|last=Huxley|first=Tim|authorlink=|title=Defending the Lion City: the Armed Forces of Singapore|year=2000|publisher=Allen & Unwin Pty LTD|location=|isbn=1-86508-118-3}} * {{Cite book|last=Wing Commander C.
